Award.AwardTitle: Facility Support: The Global CMT Project
Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of the Global Centroid-Moment-Tensor Project (GCMT Project) is to analyze and quantify all moderate and large earthquakes occurring worldwide using seismic data, and to provide the most comprehensive record of global seismic strain release available. Data from global seismographic networks are collected from the IRIS Data Management Center (DMC) and from individual network operators in near-real time for the analysis of large earthquakes. Additional archived data are later retrieved from the IRIS DMC to determine final results and to investigate events of smaller magnitude.

The major objectives and activities of the GCMT Project are:
1. Systematic determination of moment tensors for earthquakes with magnitude M>5 globally, and archiving of the results in the GCMT catalog.
2. Rapid determination of moment tensors for earthquakes with M>5.5 globally, and quick dissemination of the results ("quick CMTs").
3. Curation and distribution of the GCMT catalog, which contains moment-tensor results for the period 1976 to the present, currently more than 35,000 earthquakes.
4. Routine detection and location of seismic sources using surface waves.
5. Investigation and reporting of the quality of seismic waveforms from the Global Seismographic Network other seismic networks.
6. Systematic analysis of earthquake sequences of special importance.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award supported the ongoing effort of the Global Centroid Moment Tensor Project (GCMT Project) to analyze and characterize all moderate and large earthquakes that occur worldwide using seismic data, and to provide the most comprehensive record of global strain release available. Data from global seismographic networks were collected from the IRIS Data Management Center (DMC) and from individual network operators in near-real time for the rapid analysis of large earthquakes. Additional archived data were later retrieved from the IRIS DMC to determine final results and to investigate smaller earthquakes.

The major outcomes of this project are (1) Analysis of 9,002 earthquakes with magnitudes 5.0 or greater for the time period 2013-2016, and archiving of the results in the GCMT catalog; (2) Rapid analysis of earthquakes larger than magnitude 5.5, and quick dissemination of the results (so-called quick CMTs) to researchers and institutions; (3) Curation and distribution of the GCMT catalog, which now contains earthquake parameters for more than 47,000 earthquakes for the time period 1976-2016; (4) Detection and location of seismic sources using surface waves, and automatic publication of the results on our web site; (5) Investigation and reporting of the quality of seismic waveforms from the Global Seismographic Network and other seismic networks. The research results of the project (the GCMT catalog of earthquake parameters and associated reports) are available on the project web site, www.globalcmt.org, The GCMT results are also distributed by and accessible from the United States Geological Survey, the IRIS DMC, the European-Mediterranean Seismological Centre and the International Seismological Centre.
